\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index::doc}}


Tigramite is a causal time series analysis python package. With flexibly adaptable scripts it allows to reconstruct graphical models (conditional independence graphs) from discrete or continuously-valued time series based on a causal discovery algorithm and create high-quality plots of the results.

\chapter{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{tigramite.pcmci}: PCMCI}
\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite}}\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite-pcmci-pcmci}}\index{PCMCI (class in tigramite.pcmci)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.pcmci.PCMCI}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxstrong{class }\sphinxcode{tigramite.pcmci.}\sphinxbfcode{PCMCI}}{\emph{dataframe}, \emph{cond\_ind\_test}, \emph{selected\_variables=None}, \emph{var\_names=None}, \emph{verbosity=0}}{}
PCMCI: causal discovery for time series datasets.

The implementation is based on Algorithms 1 and 2 in %
\begin{footnote}[1]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
J. Runge, D. Sejdinovic, S. Flaxman (2017): Detecting causal
associations in large nonlinear time series datasets,
\sphinxurl{https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07007}
%
\end{footnote}

PCMCI is a 2-step causal discovery method for large-scale time series
datasets. The first step is a condition-selection followed by the MCI
conditional independence test.

PCMCI allows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
different conditional independence test statistics adapted to
continuously-valued or discrete data, and different assumptions about
linear or nonlinear dependencies

\item {} 
easy parallelization

\item {} 
masked time series data

\item {} 
false discovery control and confidence interval estimation

\end{itemize}
\paragraph{Notes}

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=200bp]{{mci_schematic}.pdf}

In our framework, the dependency structure of a set of time series variables
is represented in a \sphinxstyleemphasis{time series graph} as shown in the Figure. The nodes of
a time series graph are defined as the variables at different times and a
link exists if two lagged variables are \sphinxstyleemphasis{not} conditionally independent
given the past of the whole process. Assuming stationarity, the links are
repeated in time. The parents \(\mathcal{P}\) of a variable are defined
as the set of all nodes with a link towards it.

Our causal discovery technique to estimate the time series graph is based on
a two-step procedure:

1. Condition-selection: For all \(N\) variables: Estimate \sphinxstyleemphasis{superset} of
parents :math:{}`     ilde\{mathcal\{P\}\}(X\textasciicircum{}j\_t){}` with iterative PC1algorithm.
\begin{enumerate}
\setcounter{enumi}{1}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Momentary conditional independence} test

\end{enumerate}
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}ext{MCI:}~~~~X^i_{t-{   au}} ~&\perp~ X^j_{t} ~|~ \mathcal{P}(X^j_t)
            \setminus \{X^i_{t-{        au}}\},\,\mathcal{P}(X^i_{t-{   au}})\,,\end{split}
\end{equation*}
The main free parameters of this method (in addition to free parameters of
the conditional independence test statistic) are the maximum time delay
:math:{}`     au\_\{max\}{}` and the significance threshold in the PC1 step
\(lpha\). The maximum time delay depends on the application and should
be chosen according to the maximum physical time lag expected in the complex
system. \(lpha\) should not be seen as a significance test level in
PC1 since the iterative hypothesis tests do not allow for a precise
confidence level. \(lpha\) rather takes the role of a regularization
parameter in model-selection techniques. The conditioning sets
\(\mathcal{P}\) estimated with PC1 should include the true parents and
at the same time be small in size to reduce the estimation dimension of the
MCI test and improve its power. But the first demand is typically more
important. If a list of values is given or \sphinxcode{pc\_alpha=None}, this parameter
is optimized using model selection

Further minor parameters are discussed in \sphinxfootnotemark[1].
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{dataframe} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{data object}) -- This can either be the tigramite dataframe object or a pandas data
frame. It must have the attributes dataframe.values yielding a numpy
array of shape (observations T, variables N) and optionally a mask of
the same shape.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{cond\_ind\_test} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{conditional independence test object}) -- 
This can be ParCorr or other classes from the tigramite package or an
external test passed as a callable. This test can be based on the class
tigramite.independence\_tests.CondIndTest. If a callable is passed, it
must have the signature:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{CondIndTest}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} with attributes}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} * measure : str}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   name of the test}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} * use\PYGZus{}mask : bool}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   whether the mask should be used}

    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} and functions}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} * run\PYGZus{}test(X, Y, Z, tau\PYGZus{}max) : where X,Y,Z are of the form}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   X = [(var, \PYGZhy{}tau)]  for non\PYGZhy{}negative integers var and tau}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   specifying the variable and time lag}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   return (test statistic value, p\PYGZhy{}value)}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} * set\PYGZus{}dataframe(dataframe) : set dataframe object}

    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} optionally also}

    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} * get\PYGZus{}model\PYGZus{}selection\PYGZus{}criterion(j, parents) : required if}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   pc\PYGZus{}alpha parameter is to be optimized. Here j is the}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   variable index and parents a list [(var, \PYGZhy{}tau), ...]}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   return score for model selection}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} * get\PYGZus{}confidence(X, Y, Z, tau\PYGZus{}max) : required for}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   return\PYGZus{}confidence=True}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   estimate confidence interval after run\PYGZus{}test was called}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}   return (lower bound, upper bound)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{selected\_variables} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{list of integers}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: range}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{(}{\hyperref[\detokenize{index:PCMCI.N}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{N}}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Specify to estimate parents only for selected variables. If None is
passed, parents are estimated for all variables.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{var\_names} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{list of strings}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: range}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{(}{\hyperref[\detokenize{index:PCMCI.N}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{N}}}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Names of variables, must match the number of variables. If None is
passed, variables are enumerated as {[}0, 1, ...{]}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{verbosity} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 0}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Verbose levels 0, 1, ...

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

Returns p-values corrected for multiple testing.

Wrapper around statsmodels.sandbox.stats.multicomp.multipletests.
Corrections is performed either among all links if
exclude\_contemporaneous==False, or only among lagged links.

\item {}

\index{run\_mci() (tigramite.pcmci.PCMCI method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}

MCI conditional independence tests.

Implements the MCI test (Algorithm 2 in \sphinxfootnotemark[1]). Returns the matrices of
test statistic values,  p-values, and confidence intervals.

specifying whether only selected links should be tested. If None is
passed, all links are tested

\item {}

\end{itemize}

and the matrix conf\_matrix is of shape (N, N, tau\_max+1, 2)

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
tuple of arrays

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

a larger number, such as 10, can be used.

\index{run\_pcmci() (tigramite.pcmci.PCMCI method)}

Run full PCMCI causal discovery for time series datasets.

Wrapper around PC-algorithm function and MCI function.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{save\_iterations} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{bool}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: False}) -- Whether to save iteration step results such as conditions used.

\item {}

to test. Defaults to 1 for PC\_1 algorithm. For original PC algorithm
a larger number, such as 10, can be used.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{max\_conds\_py} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ or }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{None}) -- Maximum number of conditions of Y to use. If None is passed, this
number is unrestricted.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{max\_conds\_px} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ or }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{None}) -- Maximum number of conditions of Z to use. If None is passed, this
number is unrestricted.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{fdr\_method} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 'fdr\_bh'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Correction method, default is Benjamini-Hochberg False Discovery
Rate method.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{(val\_matrix, p\_matrix, conf\_matrix)} -- The matrices val\_matrix and p\_matrix are of shape (N, N, tau\_max+1)
and the matrix conf\_matrix is of shape (N, N, tau\_max+1, 2)

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
tuple of arrays

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

Base class of conditional independence tests.

Provides useful general functions for different independence tests such as
shuffle significance testing and bootstrap confidence estimation. Also
handles masked samples. Other test classes can inherit from this class.

\index{GPACE (class in tigramite.independence\_tests)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.independence_tests.GPACE}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxstrong{class }\sphinxcode{tigramite.independence\_tests.}\sphinxbfcode{GPACE}}{\emph{null\_dist\_filename=None}, \emph{gp\_version='new'}, \emph{gp\_kernel=None}, \emph{gp\_alpha=None}, \emph{gp\_restarts=None}, \emph{ace\_version='acepack'}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
GPACE conditional independence test.

GPACE is based on a Gaussian process (GP) regression and a maximal
correlation test on the residuals. GP is estimated with scikit-learn and
allows to flexibly specify kernels and hyperparameters or let them be
optimized automatically. The maximal correlation test is implemented with
the ACE estimator either from a pure python implementation (slow) or, if rpy
is available, using the R-package `acepack'. Here the null distribution is
not analytically available, but can be precomputed with the script
`generate\_gpace\_nulldist.py' which generates a *.npz file containing the
null distribution for different sample sizes.
\paragraph{Notes}

As described in \sphinxfootnotemark[1], GPACE is based on a Gaussian
process (GP) regression and a maximal correlation test on the residuals. To
test \(X \perp Y | Z\), first  \(Z\) is regressed out from \(X\)
and \(Y\) assuming the  model
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}X & =  f_X(Z) + \epsilon_{X} \\
Y & =  f_Y(Z) + \epsilon_{Y}  \\
\epsilon_{X,Y} &\sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
using GP regression. Here \(\sigma^2\) corresponds to the gp\_alpha
parameter. Then the residuals  are transformed to uniform
marginals yielding \(r_X,r_Y\) and their dependency is tested with
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\max_{g,h}\rho\left(g(r_X),h(r_Y)\right)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
where \(g,h\) yielding maximal correlation are obtained using the
Alternating Conditional Expectation (ACE) algorithm. The null distribution
of the maximal correlation can be pre-computed.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{null\_dist\_filename} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{otional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Path to file containing null distribution. If None is passed, the
default filename generated by the script \sphinxquotedblleft{}generate\_gpace\_nulldist.py\sphinxquotedblright{}
is used.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{gp\_version} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\{'new'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{'old'\}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 'new'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- The older GP version from scikit-learn 0.17 was used for the numerical
simulations in \sphinxfootnotemark[1]. The newer version from scikit-learn 0.19 is faster
and allows more flexibility regarding kernels etc.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{gp\_kernel} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{kernel object}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Only available for gp\_version='new'. Can be any scikit-learn kernel
object available in gaussian\_process.kernels. The kernel specifies the
covariance function of the GP. If None is passed, the kernel `1.0 *
RBF(1.0)' is used as default. Note that the kernel's hyperparameters are
optimized during fitting.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{gp\_alpha} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{float}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ or }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array-like}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Only available for gp\_version='new'. Value added to the diagonal of the
kernel matrix during fitting. Larger values correspond to increased
noise level in the observations and reduce potential numerical issues
during fitting. If an array is passed, it must have the same number of
entries as the data used for fitting and is used as datapoint-dependent
noise level. Note that this is equivalent to adding a WhiteKernel with
c=alpha. If None is passed, gp\_alpha=1 is used.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{gp\_restarts} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Only available for gp\_version='new'. The number of restarts of the
optimizer for finding the kernel's parameters which maximize the log-
marginal likelihood. The first run of the optimizer is performed from
the kernel's initial parameters, the remaining ones (if any) from thetas
sampled log-uniform randomly from the space of allowed theta-values. If
greater than 0, all bounds must be finite. If None is passed,
n\_restarts\_optimizer=0 is used, implying that one run is performed.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{ace\_version} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\{'python'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{'acepack'\}}) -- Estimator for ACE estimator of maximal correlation to use. `python'
loads the very slow pure python version available from
\sphinxurl{https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ace/0.3}. `acepack' loads the much faster
version from the R-package acepack. This requires the R-interface
rpy2 to be installed and acepack needs to be installed in R beforehand.
Note that both versions `python' and `acepack' may result in different
results. In \sphinxfootnotemark[1] the acepack version was used.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{**kwargs} -- Arguments passed on to parent class CondIndTest.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{get\_analytic\_significance() (tigramite.independence\_tests.GPACE method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.independence_tests.GPACE.get_analytic_significance}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{get\_analytic\_significance}}{\emph{value}, \emph{df}}{}
Returns p-value for the maximal correlation coefficient.

The null distribution is loaded and the entry for the nearest available
degrees of freedom (df) is used. If it is different by more than 1\% from
the actual sample size, an error is raised. Then the null distribution
has to be generated with the script \sphinxquotedblleft{}generate\_gpace\_nulldist.py\sphinxquotedblright{}. The
maximal correlation coefficient is one-sided. If the degrees of freedom
are less than 1, numpy.nan is returned.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{value} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{float}) -- Test statistic value.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{df} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}) -- degrees of freedom of the test, given by T - dim

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{pval} -- P-value.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
float or numpy.nan

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{CMIknn (class in tigramite.independence\_tests)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.independence_tests.CMIknn}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxstrong{class }\sphinxcode{tigramite.independence\_tests.}\sphinxbfcode{CMIknn}}{\emph{knn=100}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Conditional mutual information test based on nearest-neighbor estimator.

Conditional mutual information is the most general dependency measure
coming from an information-theoretic framework. It makes no assumptions
about the parametric form of the dependencies by directly estimating the
underlying joint density. The test here is based on the estimator in  S.
Frenzel and B. Pompe, Phys. Rev. Lett. 99, 204101 (2007), combined with a
shuffle test to generate  the distribution under the null hypothesis of
independence. The knn-estimator is suitable only for variables taking a
continuous range of values. For discrete variables use the CMIsymb class.
\paragraph{Notes}

CMI is given by
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}I(X;Y|Z) &= \int p(z)  \iint  p(x,y|z) \log
\frac{ p(x,y |z)}{p(x|z)\cdot p(y |z)} \,dx dy dz\end{split}
\end{equation*}
Its knn-estimator is given by
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\widehat{I}(X;Y|Z)  &=   \psi (k) + \frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=1}^T
\left[ \psi(k_{Z,t}) - \psi(k_{XZ,t}) - \psi(k_{YZ,t}) \right]\end{split}
\end{equation*}
where \(\psi\) is the Digamma function.  This estimator has as a
parameter the number of nearest-neighbors \(k\) which determines the
size of hyper-cubes around each (high-dimensional) sample point. Then
\(k_{Z,},k_{XZ},k_{YZ}\) are the numbers of neighbors in the respective
subspaces.

\(k\) can be viewed as a density smoothing parameter (although it is
data-adaptive unlike fixed-bandwidth estimators). For large \(k\), the
underlying dependencies are more smoothed and CMI has a larger bias,
but lower variance, which is more important for significance testing. Note
that the estimated CMI values can be slightly negative while CMI is a non-
negative quantity.

This class requires the scipy.spatial.cKDTree package and the tigramite
cython module.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{knn} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 100}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Number of nearest-neighbors which determines the size of hyper-cubes
around each (high-dimensional) sample point.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{**kwargs} -- Arguments passed on to parent class CondIndTest.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{CMIsymb (class in tigramite.independence\_tests)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.independence_tests.CMIsymb}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxstrong{class }\sphinxcode{tigramite.independence\_tests.}\sphinxbfcode{CMIsymb}}{\emph{**kwargs}}{}
Conditional mutual information test based on discrete estimator.

Conditional mutual information is the most general dependency measure
coming from an information-theoretic framework. It makes no assumptions
about the parametric form of the dependencies by directly estimating the
underlying joint density. The test here is based on directly estimating
the joint distribution assuming symbolic input, combined with a
shuffle test to generate  the distribution under the null hypothesis of
independence. The knn-estimator is suitable only for discrete variables.
For continuous variables, either pre-process the data using the functions
in data\_processing or use the CMIknn class.
\paragraph{Notes}

CMI and its estimator are given by
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}I(X;Y|Z) &= \sum p(z)  \sum \sum  p(x,y|z) \log
\frac{ p(x,y |z)}{p(x|z)\cdot p(y |z)} \,dx dy dz\end{split}
\end{equation*}\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{**kwargs} -- Arguments passed on to parent class CondIndTest.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{ordinal\_patt\_array() (in module tigramite.data\_processing)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.data_processing.ordinal_patt_array}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{tigramite.data\_processing.}\sphinxbfcode{ordinal\_patt\_array}}{\emph{array}, \emph{array\_mask}, \emph{dim=2}, \emph{step=1}, \emph{weights=False}, \emph{verbosity=0}}{}
Returns symbolified array of ordinal patterns.

Each data vector (X\_t, ..., X\_t+(dim-1)*step) is converted to its rank
vector. E.g., (0.2, -.6, 1.2) --\textgreater{} (1,0,2) which is then assigned to a
unique integer (see Article). There are faculty(dim) possible rank vectors.

Note that the symb\_array is step*(dim-1) shorter than the original array!

Reference: B. Pompe and J. Runge (2011). Momentary information transfer as
a coupling measure of time series. Phys. Rev. E, 83(5), 1-12.
doi:10.1103/PhysRevE.83.051122
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{array} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array-like}) -- Data array of shape (time, variables).

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{array\_mask} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{bool array}) -- Data mask where True labels masked samples.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{dim} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 2}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Pattern dimension

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{step} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 1}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Delay of pattern embedding vector.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{weights} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{bool}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: False}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Whether to return array of variances of embedding vectors as weights.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{verbosity} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 0}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Level of verbosity.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{patt, patt\_mask {[}, patt\_time{]}} -- Tuple of converted pattern array and new length

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
tuple of arrays

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{smooth() (in module tigramite.data\_processing)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.data_processing.smooth}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{tigramite.data\_processing.}\sphinxbfcode{smooth}}{\emph{data}, \emph{smooth\_width}, \emph{kernel='gaussian'}, \emph{mask=None}, \emph{residuals=False}}{}
Returns either smoothed time series or its residuals.

the difference between the original and the smoothed time series
(=residuals) of a kernel smoothing with gaussian (smoothing kernel width =
twice the sigma!) or heaviside window, equivalent to a running mean.

Assumes data of shape (T, N) or (T,)
:rtype: array
:returns: smoothed/residual data
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{smooth\_width} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{float}) -- Window width of smoothing, 2*sigma for a gaussian.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{kernel} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 'gaussian'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Smoothing kernel, `gaussian' or `heaviside' for a running mean.

\item {}

\item {}

\index{var\_process() (in module tigramite.data\_processing)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.data_processing.var_process}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{tigramite.data\_processing.}\sphinxbfcode{var\_process}}{\emph{parents\_neighbors\_coeffs}, \emph{T=1000}, \emph{use='inv\_inno\_cov'}, \emph{verbosity=0}}{}
Returns a vector-autoregressive process with correlated innovations.

Wrapper around var\_network with possibly more user-friendly input options.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{parents\_neighbors\_coeffs} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{dict}) -- Dictionary of format \{..., j:{[}(var1, lag1), (var2, lag2), ...{]}, ...\} for
all variables where vars must be in {[}0..N-1{]} and lags \textless{}= 0 with number
of variables N. If lag=0, a nonzero value in the covariance matrix (or
its inverse) is implied. These should be the same for (i, j) and (j, i).

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{use} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 'inv\_inno\_cov'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Specifier, either `inno\_cov' or `inv\_inno\_cov'.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{T} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 1000}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Sample size.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{verbosity} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 0}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Level of verbosity.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstylestrong{X} -- Array of realization.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
array-like

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\chapter{\sphinxstyleliteralintitle{tigramite.plotting}: Plotting functions}
\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite-plotting-plotting-functions}}\label{\detokenize{index:module-tigramite.plotting}}\index{tigramite.plotting (module)}
Tigramite plotting package.
\index{plot\_graph() (in module tigramite.plotting)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:tigramite.plotting.plot_graph}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{tigramite.plotting.}\sphinxbfcode{plot\_graph}}{\emph{val\_matrix}, \emph{var\_names=None}, \emph{fig\_ax=None}, \emph{sig\_thres=None}, \emph{link\_matrix=None}, \emph{save\_name=None}, \emph{link\_colorbar\_label='MCI'}, \emph{node\_colorbar\_label='auto-MCI'}, \emph{link\_width=None}, \emph{node\_pos=None}, \emph{arrow\_linewidth=30.0}, \emph{vmin\_edges=-1}, \emph{vmax\_edges=1.0}, \emph{edge\_ticks=0.4}, \emph{cmap\_edges='RdBu\_r'}, \emph{vmin\_nodes=0}, \emph{vmax\_nodes=1.0}, \emph{node\_ticks=0.4}, \emph{cmap\_nodes='OrRd'}, \emph{node\_size=20}, \emph{arrowhead\_size=20}, \emph{curved\_radius=0.2}, \emph{label\_fontsize=10}, \emph{alpha=1.0}, \emph{node\_label\_size=10}, \emph{link\_label\_fontsize=6}, \emph{network\_lower\_bound=0.2}}{}
Creates a network plot.

This is still in beta. The network is defined either from True values in
link\_matrix, or from thresholding the val\_matrix with sig\_thres.  Nodes
denote variables, straight links contemporaneous dependencies and curved
arrows lagged dependencies. The node color denotes the maximal absolute
auto-dependency and the link color the value at the lag with maximal
absolute cross-dependency. The link label lists the lags with significant
dependency in order of absolute magnitude. The network can also be plotted
over a map drawn before on the same axis. Then the node positions can be
supplied in appropriate axis coordinates via node\_pos.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{val\_matrix} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array\_like}) -- Matrix of shape (N, N, tau\_max+1) containing test statistic values.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{var\_names} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{list}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- List of variable names. If None, range(N) is used.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{fig\_ax} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{tuple of figure and axis object}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Figure and axes instance. If None they are created.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{sig\_thres} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array-like}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Matrix of significance thresholds. Must be of same shape as  val\_matrix.
Either sig\_thres or link\_matrix has to be provided.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{link\_matrix} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{bool array-like}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Matrix of significant links. Must be of same shape as val\_matrix. Either
sig\_thres or link\_matrix has to be provided.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{save\_name} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Name of figure file to save figure. If None, figure is shown in window.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{link\_colorbar\_label} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 'MCI'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Test statistic label.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{node\_colorbar\_label} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{str}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: 'auto-MCI'}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Test statistic label for auto-dependencies.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{link\_width} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array-like}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Array of val\_matrix.shape specifying relative link width with maximum
given by arrow\_linewidth. If None, all links have same width.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{node\_pos} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{dictionary}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{, }\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{optional}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{ (}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{default: None}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{)}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{}) -- Dictionary of node positions in axis coordinates of form
node\_pos = \{`x':array of shape (N,), `y':array of shape(N)\}. These
coordinates could have been transformed before for basemap plots.

\item {}

Create matrix of lag function panels.

Class to setup figure object. The function add\_lagfuncs(...) allows to plot
the val\_matrix of shape (N, N, tau\_max+1). Multiple lagfunctions can be
overlaid for comparison.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{N} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{int}) -- Number of variables

\item {}

\item {}

is used.
